reviewText: This has been my favorite new Christmas movie in recent years. Steve Guttenberg is a warm, gentle, and romantic Santa who makes my toes curl, but who also also possesses a natural understanding and affection for children that would melt anyone's heart. Crystal Bernard is perfect as a loving single mom full of energy and feistiness, trying to hide a wounded spirit and deep loneliness. The two of them are magic together on the screen, and the film has one of the most touching happy endings of any movie around. Buy it and watch it with a cup of hot chocolate and a fuzzy blanket. It's a winner.

reviewText: Single Santa Seeks Mrs. Clausis kind of like a made-for-TV version ofSanta Clause 2, but with fewer special effects and more charm. Nick (Steve Guttenberg) plays Santa's son, who must find a wife by Christmas day if he wants to take over his father's job as the new Santa. He soon meets Beth (Crystal Bernard) and falls in love. In the meantime, Nick is the personification of goodness and the Christmas spirit. He treats Beth's son as his own and helps those he meets. In other films, Guttenberg's style of acting might seem awkward or goofy, but it fitsSingle Santa Seeks Mrs. Clausperfectly. The only problem is that the movie ends a bit too quickly. It seems the relationship was just about to get started when the movie ends. It could have been at least a half-hour longer, which would have made it a 5-star film.

reviewText: I just caught the engaging SINGLE SANTA SEEKS MRS. CLAUS on the Hallmark Channel and liked it well enough that, now, I want to throw my two cents in. Steve Guttenberg (POLICE ACADEMY, THREE MEN AND A BABY, COCOON) plays Nick, the bachelor offspring of the real Santa Claus, who, in a year's time, is slated to take over his old man's traditional position. But, first, he needs to get himself a wife and he needs to do it before Christmas eve. In search of such, he journeys to sunny California and bumps into Beth (Crystal Bernard, WINGS), an overworked ad exec and single mom, who is very practical and doesn't believe in Santa Claus. What follows is Nick's courtship of Beth and her little boy Jake, who, by the way, though liking Nick a lot, seems to be the only one to notice something weird about him. Of course, since a movie isn't a movie without some conflict, what we get is a harried Beth, constantly being pressured by her boss about various work projects, who must ultimately decide between her vocational advancement and her personal life.This being a Christmas family movie and a Hallmark one, at that, it tends to suffer from being a little too treacly. But Guttenberg's warmth, boyish likability and his chemistry with the lovely Bernard go a long way to make the sometimes cloying sentimentality palatable. There are nice touches here as Nick covertly applies his magical abilities to make things and the people around him better (Nick magically enabling a store Santa to communicate with a deaf girl is particularly neat). But, seemingly, what works best for Nick is his innate, jovial charm and indiscriminating friendliness to everyone. Just witness his easy rapport with the child actress who couldn't remember her line and was subsequently yelled at by the old actor playing Santa for a commercial.There are no special effects to speak of, and, really, none are required. The performances of the actors and the cute premise are endearing enough that the viewer is swayed early on to suspend belief and buy into the unlikely plot. Of course, it helps that it's shown predominantly around the holidays. I honestly had fun watching this movie, which, in my opinion, is superior to the boorish SANTA CLAUSE 2. And, thanks to the reviewers here, I just found out that there's a sequel; so I'll just have to keep my eyes open for MEET THE SANTAS.
summary: "I'm gonna have Santa for a dad!"

reviewText: This is a great family Christmas film -- there's something in it to satisfy every family member. Steve Gutenberg and Crystal Bernard are wonderful as the couple fated to be Mr. and Mrs. Santa. Of course, he must conquer her sense of disbelief created on that sad Christmas morning when Santa could not fulfill her wish when she was a young child. Brilliantly, that sad moment is turned around at the film's conclusion, bringing back her sense of magic. (I defy anyone not to shed a tear during that scene!!)I am a fan of Christmas movies any time of year, and Single Santa Seeks Mrs. Claus is a particular favorite. Sincerely recommended for people of all ages!

reviewText: I love this movie, but I gave it one star because of technical difficulties.  Despite the fact that the description of the DVD states that it includes close-captioning, that is not the case!  I am hearing impaired and my DVD purchases are limited to those with English subtitles or close-captioning,  I relied on the information provided when I decided to buy this DVD; however, when I tried to play the movie for the first time, I was very disappointed to learn that there are no subtitles of any kind included.  Not only did I waste my time and money, but I also can't enjoy the movie I wanted to see.  There are two problems related to the subtitling issue.  The first is the problem I found with Single Santa; the description states there is captioning when there is not.  The second problem is one I have found in many other cases; the description does not give any information about captioning so I pass up the purchase only to learn from a friend or relative who has the DVD that captioning is included.  All nine seasons of Perry Mason fall into this category.  All are subtitled, but you will never know it by reading the descriptions unless they have been updated recently.  Also, there may be several seasons of a TV show offered for sale, but the descriptions include subtitling for only one season.  When the same company produced all the DVDs, is it likely only one would include captioning?  Who knows, but without information, I am forced to pass up these purchases.  There are thousands of customers with hearing problems and we are at the mercy of what is printed in these description.  We deserve better than we are getting; please, Amazon, make sure these descriptions include all the information and that what is included is accurate!
summary: If you are hearing impaired, be warned - no subtitles or close-captioning!

reviewText: When this was first on Hallmark I thought "Ok, a knock off of The Santa Clause 2 & that series. (Which I thought was kinda of stupid anyway).." Well I watched it and ended up really loving it. Sure it's sentimental, but it's very cute and I like the story line better than the Tim Allen movies. I like Steve Guttenberg as Nick, he's very cute and endearing in the role. He and Crystal Bernard have a good chemistry together ! Bernard is good as the overwrought, loving single Mom and so funny too ! I ended up buying this video for myself and my retired parents.They made a sequel "Meet the Santas" which I liked very much, was even funnier than the first one, but I have yet to see it on DVD. Wish they would release it so I can get it ! Hey Hallmark come on !You'll have a cozy, enjoyable time watching this movie. Happy Holidays !

reviewText: This film was originally shown on the Hallmark channel in 2004 and I know it is being repeated this year.  It's a sappy charmer but the best Christmas movies tend to be sappy charmers anyway and this one does a very good job.  The movie stars Steve Guttenberg who had really kind of disappeared for a few years but seems to be making a but of a comeback even if it's not in A features.Guttenberg is Nick, the son of Santa Claus.  His dad is retiring and Nick is going to take over the job but before he can he has to find a Mrs. Claus.  Now obviously this is same plot used in the Santa Clause 2 so while it's not terribly original, it's pulled off well for a TV movie.  Anyway he heads to Southern California where he eventually meets Beth played by Crystal Bernard.  He of coruse has to win Beth over and convince her to believe in Santa.  Beth is a hard-working career woman, widower, and mother who has a son named Jake.  She works for an ad agency and Nick actually plays Santa in commercials that the company does.  Well of course you know how the film turns out, right?Guttenberg is always a likable guy and brings a regular guy charm to his roles.  Bernard is equally likable, always playing the nice girl.  It's a good family picture.  Hallmark had made a sequel called "Meet the Santas" which should be popping up any day now.  As they say...check your listings!

reviewText: I caught this film on the Hallmark Channel over Thanksgiving weekend.  Along with its sequel (Meet The Santas, not out on DVD) it is a GREAT holiday movie.  I have to admit, I went in with no expectations, but was pleasantly surprised with the "new" twist on holiday traditions.  More than a belief vs. non-belief movie, this film breaks the molds and sets a new standard for holiday film magic.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

reviewText: Grab your blanket and get all snug on your couch! Steve Guttenbergs' character Nick was so sweet and some of the things he said were so touching that I just get all squeaky-voiced just thinking about it! I was surprised too because I haven't seen ol' Steve since, what, 1985? I was a little skeptical, but I'm glad I decided to buy it. Cyrstal Bernard (Beth) is good on here too. I haven't seen her since "Wings" and it was nice watching her spunk again. This is a movie about Santa's son who needs to find a wife and comes across an overworked, stressed out widow with a young son. She has a hard time believing in anything that can bring joy let alone St. Nick. The question is will Beth open her heart to Nick and just let go and believe? The little kid that plays her son was adorable! I totally recommend this movie for anyone who loves easy, sweet, romantic movies that are especially Christmas oriented.
